webTitle: Barclays opens up its branches for credit unions to use

fields.standfirst: Bank will allow financial co-operatives to set up shop as well as access its mobile payments technology as part of £1m package
fields.body:
Last summer the archbishop of Canterbury proposed that credit unions should be able to use church halls. Now Barclays has arguably gone one better by announcing it will be allowing them to set up shop in its branches – and they will not have to pay for the privilege.

The high street bank is also giving Britain's credit unions free access to its latest mobile payments technology as part of a £1m package of help for the sector, which is seen as offering a vital alternative to expensive payday lenders, loan sharks – and banks.

Credit unions are financial co-operatives, and Barclays said it was pledging the money because they provided a vital service to more than a million people across the country.

But some may be surprised that the bank is effectively allowing competitors to use its branches for free, bearing in mind that the established high street players and credit unions are increasingly targeting the same customers.

Britain's credit unions have traditionally specialised in loans and savings for the less well-off, but the rules governing the way they operate have been loosened and many are now targeting people of all incomes. More than 20 credit unions offer current accounts that typically come with a debit card and most other features a bank customer would expect, but often do not provide a full online banking service. Some offer cash Isas and a handful have branched out into mortgages.

Announcing the new £1m fund, which will be managed by the Toynbee Hall charity, Barclays said it would be opening up space within its branches across the UK "to provide dedicated community hubs that can be used free of charge by credit unions and other community groups".

The bank added that it would be offering credit unions free infrastructure access to Pingit, Barclays's mobile phone payment service launched in 2012, so they could operate mobile payments without needing to invest in technology. It will also offer support through specialist volunteering.

Ashok Vaswani, chief executive of the bank's retail and business banking division, said: "This new commitment will help people who have been historically neglected by the sector, to put them on a more secure footing and give them the chance to fully participate in our economy again."

In July 2013, the archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, said he was throwing the weight of the church behind credit unions to offer an alternative to Wonga and other payday lenders. He offered to open up thousands of churches to existing credit unions.

Bank of England figures show that the total number of credit union members in Britain nearly doubled from 562,000 in 2004 to almost 1.04 million in 2012. But the number of active credit unions in Britain fell from 565 in 2004 to around 380 now.

webTitle: Siemens enters Alstom takeover battle with General Electric

fields.standfirst: German company submits offer after Paris encourages EU firms to do so to head off $13bn GE bid for France's Alstom
fields.body:
Germany's Siemens has formally entered into a takeover battle with the US's General Electric for Alstom, the French company that makes Eurostar trains.

Siemen's official offer on Tuesday came after the French government encouraged European firms to submit rival bids to head off GE's $13bn (£7.7bn) surprise takeover offer.

The German firm is also in talks with Rolls-Royce to buy the British company's gas turbines business for almost £1bn. Rolls confirmed on Tuesday night that the talks are at a late stage but cautioned that the deal has not been signed and refused to comment on the price, which is understood to be between £900m-£1bn.

The group, saved from bankruptcy by the French state a decade ago, employs 18,000 people in France and has a market value of about €8.3bn (£6.8bn).

President François Hollande has met the head of GE, Jeffrey Immelt, as well as Siemens's chief executive, Joe Kaeser, and its chairman, Gerhard Cromme.

Alstom looked almost certain to fall into GE's hands until France's economy minister intervened on Sunday. Arnaud Montebourg made it clear that he was actively seeking "other solutions" to the GE bid, telling reporters that Paris "is expressing its patriotic concern and vigilance".

He added: "We are working to improve the offers to make sure that French companies … do not become prey. On the other hand we are open to alliances that help to equip us for globalisation.

"We've already got an extra 48 hours since Sunday evening. We will now get the necessary time to ensure national industrial interests are preserved."

Montebourg has called on Alstom to take a month to evaluate the bids and has refused to rule out nationalisation of its nuclear power business, which is considered a nationally strategic asset.

Montebourg told the French parliament on Tuesday: "An offer by German company Siemens is being presented. It is currently being submitted into the hands of the board of Alstom," before Siemens could release news its intention.

Montebourg's comments forced Siemens into releasing a hurried statement. "The managing board and the supervisory board of Siemens decided on Tuesday to make an offer to Alstom," it said. "The prerequisite for this offer is, that Alstom agrees to give Siemens access to the company's data room and permission to interview the management during a period of four weeks, to enable Siemens to carry out a suitable due diligence. A letter in this regard was submitted this afternoon to the French company."

Siemens, which makes Germany's ICE high-speed trains, is said to have approached Alstom with a proposal to exchange part of its train business and cash for the French firm's power arm.

GE is reported to have offered $13bn for Alstom's power turbines division, which contributes 70% of its revenues.

Montebourg also expressed annoyance at Alstom's chief executive, Patrick Kron, over claims he kept the government in the dark about negotiations with GE.

He said he had asked Kron several times since about rumoured GE interest and each time the Alstom boss had said there were no plans in the pipeline.

"Must the economy minister set up a lie detector in his office for the heads of blue chip companies who don't have the basic sense of civic duty to warn their governments?" Montebourg said.

webTitle: Skip McGee's departure from Barclays could mean an overhaul is on the way

fields.bodyText: Ignore the explanation from Barclays for why Skip McGee, its best-known and perhaps best-paid investment banker, is hopping off. It strains credibility to suggest that it's all because McGee is a deal-doing kinda guy at a moment when the head of Barclays Americas should be a specialist in regulation. It is far more likely that McGee doesn't like the look of Antony Jenkins's latest strategic masterplan. After all, the technical task of meeting the requirements of section 165 of the Dodd-Frank Act as it relates to intermediate holding companies is surely one that could be delegated to lawyers. If McGee wanted to stay at Barclays – and if Jenkins really wanted to keep him – it would have been a simple matter to find a fudge. Has Jenkins finally accepted that Barclays cannot be beholden to its big-name bankers, especially McGee's ex-Lehman Brothers crew in the US? Let's hope so because last year's cave-in on bonuses was a failure in almost every respect. Jenkins, in the face of falling profits, abandoned his "pay for performance" mantra and instead spouted feeble lines about the risk of a "death spiral"– a tired old cliche, as Robert Pickering, successful former boss of Cazenove, said this week. Some of the supposed stars left anyway and some major shareholders, including Standard Life, were annoyed. A fresh start for Barclays in investment banking, accompanied by big cuts in costs, was the only logical response after last year's mess. If McGee didn't approve, that's life. We will discover next week whether Jenkins's latest thinking on how to give shareholders a fairer slice of returns from investment banking is credible. He will also have to explain if, and why, he has lost his fear of the "death spiral". But Barclays shareholders should not be alarmed by the departure of McGee. On the contrary, it may be a small sign that Jenkins has accepted – finally – that it is time to get serious in overhauling the investment bank.

webTitle: Boardroom director forced to leave the Co-operative Group

fields.bodyText: The Co-operative Group faced fresh turmoil after one of its boardroom directors was forced to leave. The lossmaking chain of supermarkets, funeral homes and pharmacies said in a terse two-line statement that Stuart Ramsay had left the board with immediate effect after "an independent report, and at the request of the board". Ramsay, one of the 15 representatives of the Co-op regions on the board, is understood to have left after an investigation into leaks of confidential board materials. Co-op, which lost £2.5bn in 2013 after what it described as the most disastrous year in its 150-year history, is known to be using investigators from Kroll to establish the source of leaks.Ramsay's profile on the Co-op Group website describes him as a computer technician and a member of the Scotland & Northern Ireland regional board, one of the seven which are able to elect representatives to the board. The remaining five seats on the board are held by members of the independent co-operatives who own around 22% of the business, including the chair Ursula Lidbetter who runs the Lincolnshire Co-op. Another representative of the regional boards, Munir Malik, has been suspended after it emerged that he had erroneously claimed to be a chartered accountant. The latest upheaval on the board comes before a report by former civil servant Sir Christopher Kelly into events at the Co-op bank before last year's emergency £1.5bn fund raising. His report – promised this week – is expected to be followed by ideas from Lord Myners about overhauling the way the UK's largest mutual is run. The Kelly report is looking back as far as the bank's merger with the Britannia Building Society in 2009. Myners, who was chairman of Guardian Media Group until he became City minister during the 2008 banking crisis, is to leave the board next month after just five months following resistance to his plans to reform the Group. He has been leading an effort to overhaul the boardroom structure and the way the eight million members of the Co-op have their voices heard. His ideas are to be put to the Co-op annual meeting on May 17 although Myners has previously said he does think there is much chance of them being supported by the delegates who will attend. A report in the Observer last May led to the resignation of chief executive Euan Sutherland, who branded the Group "ungovernaable". Sutherland's temporary stand-in – Richard Pennycook – described the 2013 performance as disastrous when it reported £2.5bn of losses earlier this month. At the time the Group blamed "fundamental failings in management and governance at the group over many years" for the losses which were caused by the problems inside the bank as well as a write-down in the value of the acquisition of the Somerfield supermarket chain. Sutherland will not take a £1.5m retention bonus but is still in line to receive up to £1.5m of other payments after taking the top job in May last year. Pennycook has also received a £750,000 retention bonus. The Group has to decide whether to pump another £100m into the bank, which needs to raise £400m on top of last year's £1.5bn. If it does not put more cash into the bank then its shareholding will fall to below 30%.

webTitle: Anglo Irish Bank pair avoid prison despite being found guilty

fields.standfirst: Judge rules out jail term because regulator failed to warn Patrick Whelan and William McAteer about illegality of loan scheme
fields.body:
Two former Anglo Irish Bank executives have been spared jaily despite being found guilty of handing out illegal loans from the financial institution at the heart of Ireland's economic collapse.

Justice Martin Nolan said it would be wrong to jail Patrick Whelan, the bank's former head of lending in Ireland, and William McAteer, its former chief risk and finance officer, because the then financial regulator failed to warn them about the illegality of their attempt to prop up the bank's share price with a loan scheme.

Neither of the men – who were given community service instead – made any comment to the media as they left the court in Dublin on Tuesday afternoon.

The judge said it would be unjust to impose custodial sentences after Whelan, 52, and McAteer, 63. The pair had faced up to seven years in prison after being convicted of breaking the law by lending tens of millions of euros to 10 investors just months before Anglo Irish imploded.

The decision not to send the duo to jail is likely to cause outrage across Ireland given that the Irish taxpayer had to pay more than €30bn (£24.6bn) to prevent the bank's collapse in late 2008.

Propping up Anglo Irish and two other banks accused of reckless conduct pushed the Irish Republic to the edge of bankruptcy and forced the previous government to seek a €67.5bn (£55bn) bailout from the International Monetary Fund, the European commission and the European Central Bank.

In a pointed reference to Ireland's financial watchdog at the time, the judge told the court: "I find it incredible that red lights did not go off somewhere in the regulator's office."

During the trial lawyers for Whelan and McAteer said both men did not know they were doing anything illegal in relation to a loan to the Maple 10 group of investors in the summer of 2008, and believed they had been given the legal green light for the deal from the regulator.

Brendan Grehan, Whelan's senior counsel, said: "[The banker] didn't for one moment think he was involving himself in something that was unlawful, something that would find himself before a court on indictment." Patrick Gageby, for McAteer, said there were no malign intention on the part of his client, unlike many other white collar crimes which were committed from "a base motive".

Whelan and McAteer's convictions followed the acquittal of former Anglo Irish chairman Sean FitzPatrick, who was cleared of 16 similar charges. All three had denied the charges.

The trial focussed on a deal to try and reduce the influence of Ireland's one-time richest man Seán Quinn who held millions on future shares in Anglo Irish Bank In the summer of 2008 the bank tried to sell on Quinn's control of those shares to the Maple 10 group, which the jury found was an illegal transaction in the case of McAteer and Whelan.

webTitle: No jail time for ex-Anglo Bankers; UK economy posts fastest annual growth since 2007 - business live

Latest: ex-Anglo bankers avoid jail

Can UK banks handle house price crash and new recession?

UK economy grew by 0.8% in Q1 - details start here

fields.body:
5.28pm BST

Closing summary

That's all for tonight.

Here's a quick mini-summary.

In Ireland, the two men convicted of making illegal loans in the run-up to the collapse of Anglo Irish bank have avoided prison, and been told they'll probably receive community service sentences instead.

The Judge handling the case said it would be "incredibly unfair" to jail them, given the regulators' failings over a case that gripped Ireland.

Pat Whelan and William McAteer could have been jailed for five years, after being convicted of providing unlawful assistance to Anglo investors, in a high-profile trial at Dublin's criminal courts. The news broke this afternoon, with judge Martin Nolan telling the court:

"It would be incredibly unjust to impose custodial sentences.

"I find it incredible that red lights did not go off somewhere in the Regulators office.”

Judge Nolan's decision means no Irish bankers have been jailed over the event that led to the country's deeply painful financial crisis, and forced Dublin into a €90bn bailout and years of painful austerity.

Earlier.....

The British economy is growing at its fastest annual pace since 2007, after GDP rose by 0.8% in the first three months of this year. Full coverage starts here.

The government claimed that a broad-based recovery is underway, while economists declared that the UK is currently enjoying a 'Goldilocks' phase of steady growth and calm inflation.

Shadow chancellor Ed Balls, though, warned Britain needs an economy 'built to last'.

The Bank of England has published details of its new stress tests. British banks must prove they can handle a crisis in which house prices crash, interest rates are hiked and the jobless rate soars.

Back tomorrow. Cheers. GW

5.20pm BST

4.52pm BST

Henry McDonald: Ireland loses battle to jail bankers

And here's Henry McDonald, our Ireland Correspondent, on the news that the Anglo Irish execs convicted of illegal lending in the run-up to Ireland's financial crash will definitely not be imprisoned:

The Irish State has lost the battle to jail bankers blamed for the biggest financial collapse in the country's history which nearly bankrupted the entire Republic.

A judge at the Anglo Irish Bank trial ruled on Tuesday afternoon that it would be unjust to imprison two senior executives at the now defunct institution even the pair were found guilty of illegally lending tens of millions of euros to ten rich investors just months before it went bankrupt.

Mr Justice Martin Nolan concluded it would be unfair to jail ex-Anglo Irish Bank executives William McAteer and Pat Whelen despite them now being convicted criminals because the country's financial regulator had failed to alert the bankers that their loan scheme to the so called Maple 10 in the summer of 2008 was illegal.

In his judgement in court number 19 of the Dublin Circuit Criminal Court the judge said he would decide in July if the two men had to carry out community service for their crimes.

Neither men made any comment to the media as they left the court this afternoon.

But the decision not to send the duo to jail will cause national outrage across Ireland given that the Irish taxpayer had to pay out more than €30 billion to prevent the bank's complete collapse in late 2008.

Paying for Anglo Irish's reckless lending - mainly to property speculators - alongside two other pillar banks pushed the Irish Republic to the edge of national bankruptcy and forced the previous government to seek a bail out from the IMF and European Central Bank.

In a pointed reference to the Republic's Financial Regulator at the time, the judge told the court: "It would be incredibly unjust to impose custodial sentences...I find it incredible that red lights did not go off somewhere in the Regulator's office."

Barristers for the two men argued in the case that both bankers did not know they were doing anything illegal in relation to the Maple 10 loan. The pair's legal team insisted the men believed they had been given the legal green light for the deal from the state's Financial Regulator.

Brendan Grehan Senior Counsel, for Whelan said his client “didn’t for one moment think he was involving himself in something that was unlawful, something that would find himself before a court on indictment.”

Meanwhile Patrick Gageby Senior Counsel, for McAteer, said that this was a case in which there were no malign intention on the part of his client, unlike many other white collar crimes which are committed from “a base motive”

Whelan and McAteer's onvictions followed the acquittal of former chairman Sean FitzPatrick, who walked free from court after being cleared of 16 similar charges. All three had denied the charges throughout 43 days of hearings in front of a jury.

The trial focussed on a deal to try and reduce the influence of Ireland's one time richest man Sean Quinn who held millions on future shares in the bank. In the summer of 2008 the Anglo Irish Bank tried to sell on Quinn's control of those shares to the ten wealthy investors, which the jury found in the case of both McAteer and Whelan was a wholly illegal transaction. The loans to the Maple 10 were designed to prop up the bank's share price as it faced financial meltdown amid the global economic crisis.

Today's court ruling means no Irish banker has yet been jailed over the events that brought its financial system crashing down and forced Ireland to take a €90bn bailout.
